40982240.review:
[quote][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11769719/]Больше качественных и интересных обзоров на кураторской страничке Dreams of Genesis.[/url][/quote]

[h1]Только для ностальгирующих старожилов [/h1]

[b]Игра на чувствах ностальгирующих фанатов – это всегда как русская рулетка: или тебе повезёт и ностальгирующие старики раскупят твою игру, или же она окажется нафиг никому не нужным устаревшим го*ном. Так как же получилось с Ion Maiden? Сейчас разберёмся. [/b]

Игра ностальгирует на фанатах классических игр вроде Duke Nukem 3D и Shadow Warrior. Идентичная графика, схожие корявые коридоры и всё тот же геймплей с деревянным отстрелом мобов. Играть нам предстоит за персонажа по имени Шелли Харрисон, которая была рождена для того, чтобы уничтожать различных тварей этого мира. Но тварей ей не дают, а вот роботов – хоть отбавляй. Местный злодей по имени Хескел выпускает на улицы кибернетическую армию, которая крушит всё на своём пути. Разумеется, Шелли в стороне не стоит и решает вступится за бедных людишек. И вот тут начинается месиво. И оно, скажу я вам, придётся по вкусу всем ценителям игр прошлого века. Задорные, адреналиновые и мясные перестрелки ждут вас в этой игре. Враги лезут со всех сторон, к тому же, постоянно пополняя бестиарий новыми представителями. У некоторых из этих представителей даже есть свои особенности, так что над ними придётся немного подумать. В целом, играется очень мощно, хоть и не долго. Я, конечно, далеко не фанат подобных «экскурсов в прошлое», но даже мне зашла стрельба на эти локациях. 

К слову о локациях. Выполнены игровые зоны до жути добротно и разнообразно. Да и детализированно, на удивление, хорошо. Конечно, это при учёте того, насколько вообще можно детализировать подобную графику. Но в целом картинка выглядит хорошо. Нигде ничего не расплывается, никакие острые углы в глаз не тычут, а на некоторых локациях так хорошо прорисована буйная зелень, что прямо глаз радуется. 
Ещё хотелось бы отметить некоторые пасхалки на этих локациях. Отличное решение от разработчиков запихнуть что-то эдакое в игру. Я, конечно, уверен, что это уже некая традиция, но всё же: мне, как ньюфагу, было забавно их раскрывать. 

Порадовало и звуковое сопровождение. Не музыкально, а именно звуковое. С музыкальным всё не очень хорошо. А вот звук действительно классный. Звуки стрельбы ощущаются так, будто это какой-то ААА-проект, а звуки некоторых мобов так и вовсе приводят в экстаз. В общем, тут тоже спору нет – круто. 

Но всё же… Сможет ли сыскать данная игра популярность? Как мне кажется, вряд ли. Единственный её шанс – активный пиар именно среди олдфагов, иначе никак. Я раньше не играл ни во что подобное, но мне понравилось. Но вот долго в этой игре находится не хочется. Перестрелки задорные, но слишком аркадно-старомодные. Сюжет хоть и есть, но его подача слишком устарела. Для молодых игроков здесь всё морально устаревшее, поэтому я и советую играть на чувствах фанатов чего-то подобного. Они вытащат проект, ведь он хорош. Просто не для всех. 

[h1]Общая оценка: 7/10[/h1]

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1264342058

40980338.review:
It's refreshing to not have to deal with the approach of more recent shooters that have a more direct A to B guided level structure, cinematic cutscene, quicktime event laden design which ends up often making the experience more linear and constrained. That feel of raw gameplay and discovery is great.

Back are the days of having the player figure things out for themselves without glowing shiny markers, waypoint huds or detailed maps. The Sprite art is awesome, Amazing level design with multiple paths.

While Doom 2016 was a great compromise of open style shooter and some linear level elements, giving you a choice to explore some or just go right for an objective with help from a map and hud if needed, this really goes back to that old mid-90s take on shooters with a smooth modern feel overtop. 

The biggest negative is having to wait for the full game! 
Playtime is around 1-2.5hrs with a couple secrets, a lot more if you try to get them all.

40974108.review:
You may be thinking: Who needs a new FPS game in the Build Engine in 2018?  Well my question is:  Who DOESN'T need a new FPS game in the Build Engine in 2018?  The Build Engine, the Engine that powered Duke Nukem 3D, Shadow Warrior and Blood is back, and better than ever.  It's great to see 3D Realms taking this route and bringing back its iconic engine to power a new game.  The world is basic 3D objects, the enemies and objects are 2D sprites and everything is pixelated, as it should be.  Though, it is 2018 and you can improve how the game looks, if you so desire.  Personally, I'm running it in pixel mode, but in widescreen because I prefer that when available.

So, in this whole new game, you play as a cop named Shelly "Bombshell" Harrison who likes shooting things and blowing things up.  She spouts cheesy one liners when she picks up guns and blows things away.  She battles freaks in a futuristic Earth that's in the process of being destroyed.  You've got to find keys to get out of levels as you battle through...  OK, it's basically Duke Nukem 3D all over again, but ist that a bad thing?

In a nutshell, this game is legit.  In totally '90s style, you're dropped in the meat grinder with some weapons and absolutely no explanation or map.  There's no arrows or path leading you to your objective, no glowing things telling you to pick them up and interact with them.  Nope, you have to figure it all out by yourself, as it should be.  Right now, the game is pretty basic.  There are a couple areas with enemies and a boss battle at the end, just like the Shareware version of Duke Nukem 3D.  You even get the whole splash screen with the benefits of buying the full version.  It's fantastic in its retro goodness.  I'm looking forward to the full version.  Also, I hope, when the full game gets released, they keep this preview area in there, so that people who missed out on Early Access can still play it and have fun. Meanwhile, until the full version comes out, I'm going to be going back through and finding the secrets I haven't found yet.  I have some, but I missed 18 in the first area and 11 in the second, so there's more to do.

40963996.review:
Can't recommend this in the current state. I'll try it again after full release.

Enemies are boring. Early stages have nothing but "dudes with guns". After a while skull-spiders start showing up and you get a boss at the end. Now compare that to duke3D, where from the very beginning enemeis could fly around, teleport, and even the "green slime" did something unique - blocked your vision.

The levels are needlessly large. Every area feels just a bit bigger than it should be and there's nothing in those areas to justify that. It all feels empty and samey. Large areas also mean that you'll sometimes have enemies shooting at you from much further than you could expect, keeping you on your toes for all the wrong reasons.

And worst of all, the performance is atrocious. My PC is not state of the art, but it far exceeds the recommended specs, and my framerate varies from around 200 to sub-30 even at low settings. Users with much more powerful machines also report frequent drops. 
I'm not an expert, but frankly, I fear this can not be remedied aside from redesigning the levels. The developers want to push the Build engine to its limits, but the truth is, the engine can't handle the size of some areas. It's not even the amount of detail, because we've seen Duke3D campaigns with more decals and props than here. It all comes down to areas being large for the sake of being large and filled with 3D objects, and it's not something the Build engine handles very well.

I can only hope that for the full campaign the creators go back to the sources and relearn the way Duke, Shadow Warrior and Blood designed their environments instead of trying to force modern level design down Build's throat.

40948127.review:
Duke Who?

Ion Maiden is a loveletter to 90s FPS where enviromental storytelling was as important as pumping bad guys full of lead. You play Shelly "Bombshell" Harrison in this prequel to the game Bombshell, and honestly this game should have been what Bombshell as this would have been a proper introduction like the classics... But her character is pretty frickin' great. She is what you would expect from 3D Realms, a one-liner shouting maniac who loves explosives and ridiculous weapons.

Ion Maiden's gameplay harks back to the 90s where you can speedrun through levels or take your time to search every nook and cranny for easter eggs and secret stashes. The levels have an A point and B point but they are generally more open than say a 'modern' FPS. I have watched other players who definitely did things differently to the way I did in Ion Maiden and saying that fills me with joy. The enemies right now feel a bit dumb, I love the design (a cult of cyborgs) but they currently don't have anything that makes them stand-out from traditional roles (grunts, shotgunners, veterans and spiderskulls) and sometimes they can get stuck on the environment. The environment is really attractive and feels like it was pulled straight out of Robocop. Perhaps most surprisingly is that the weapons are NOT hitscan, this means you need to aim, and are able to pull off headshots for efficient kills. This also applies to the enemy, they can miss and so can you.

Currently; the performance can be a bit choppy especially when the screen gets really busy. Obviously with this being a Build Engine game it looks old and the enemies are sprites instead of polygons, but I believe that works in Ion Maiden's favour. The soundtrack is currently pretty good.

I'd say wait until it's finished as two levels isn't really enough, but I love what I have currently played and really look forward to playing the finished product and seeing more environments, and enemies.

"NO GUM NEEDED."

40945351.review:
Ion Maidan is an interesting game that pretty much came out of nowhere. Since I'm a sucker for retro FPS games I purchased this the second I saw it. But, how good is it? Let's find out with the Preview Campaign.

[b]PROS:[/b] 
[list]
    [*] I liked the protagonist. A badass babe isn't something you get too often, and sometimes she even talks about the situations that happen in the game.
    [*] The visuals are nice, the Build Engine is pushed to its limits. The levels are very detailed and stylistic, there are even destructible objects. The textures aren too high-res so they don't feel too out of place with the blocky geometry of the levels.
    [*] The weapons are good. They have interesting designs and are very responsive.
    [*] The movement mechanics feel good and responsive most of the time.
    [*] Secrets are back!
    [*] Loved the voice actress, wanna hear more of her.
[/list]

[b]CONS:[/b]
[list]
    [*] The enemies are generic. Even if they all have different sprites they do all the same.
    [*] The jumps feel a little weird.
    [*] The game lags massively when the scenery changes in big places.
[/list]

[h1]Rating:[/h1]

[b]7.5 / Good.[/b] The Preview Campaign is indeed a nice throwback. There are some issues that need to be fixed but I trust they'll do it. Recommended if you want to experience the old school FPS again and / or if you want to support the devs. If not, wait till the game is completed.

I'll update this review when the complete campaign is released or if there's a major update.

40930910.review:
So far, so good.

This is yet another exelent entry among the multiple retro inspired first person shooters that we seem to be being blessed with recently, although this game takes that concept to a whole new level. Rather than trying to recreate what made those shooters of yesteryear so great using the modern graphical technology of new game engines, 3D realms gives us the genuine article by building this game on one of the game engines that started it all. This game is built upon the EDuke32 source port of the build engine, which is best known as the engine that powered such games as Duke Nukem 3D, Blood, Shadow Warrior, and Redneck Rampage. This game could sit right along side those others and if you didn't know better, you couldn't tell that this one didn't come out with the others back in the mid 90's. It feels like it has been locked away all of these years waiting for release.

Having the luxury of all of the extensions that EDuke32 is able to provide, this is by far the best looking build engine game to date, although that does come at a price. The build engine was designed in a world where 3D acceleration wasn't established yet and because of that, it isn't really able to use our modern GPU's for much of the work that it is doing. When playing this game your CPU is going to be doing most of the heavy lifting while the GPU sits idle and those people with lesser CPU's are going to see performance take a hit. It seems like the developers are working to better optimize the engine for modern hardware and hopefully we will see them implement ways of getting our GPU's into the action to smooth out performance but for now don't be supprised if you see dips in the framerate or general stuttering while playing. I personally had issues with input lag and stuttering upon first running the game and they seemed to be tied directly to the V-Sync implimentation in EDuke32. Turning V-Sync of in the in game options removed the framerate limit but seemed to leave its influence on the mouse input behind which made everything feel laggy and imprecise. I disabled V-Sync at the driver level and limited the framerate using Rivatuner and that eliminated all of the issues I was having. There is a pinned performance thread on the steam forums where the developers have offered other performance tips to get the game running better until future optimizations come along.

Overall I would recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of the old 90's style of FPS or anyone looking to get into the more fast paced open ended shooter scene. If you like this kind of thing, please throw money at them. Looking forward to future updates and the full release!

40850496.review:
Having experience and working in the game industry, I was expecting that. First, the raise of the retro style and the praise of classics, that become a model, a standard. Then the Duke Nukem 3D expansion (going to buy it soon, btw I obviously played it back in the days), and the new port for Turok. I asked myself, while playing Blood: "Hey, when AAA studios are going to publish brand-new real old-school ass-kicking games?" Five minutes later, I found Ion Maiden on Steam. I didn't know the game or either the character of Bombshell, I checked it out on Steam, and it's not much my kind of game. Au contraire, Ion Maiden IS. I mean: Jesus, seriously? Picking the old f*cking great Build Engine where splendid games like Blood, Duke Nukem and other of my most favourite games of all times run, improving it, and bringing a new super cool game? GUYS I LOVE YOU! 

This game is an instabuy even in preorder. The demo campaign is superfunny and introduces you to the game mechanics, style and mood. I also played today the bombardier mode and had a lot of fun challenging myself to win all the demo without dying (I did it!), and also I understood some mechanics about the Bowling Bombs that I didn't understand before. 

But you're here for the pros and cons, so here they are:

PROS

- Old school gameplay: uberfast action, tons of weapons, enemies exploding to pieces, blood everywhere, challenging fights, thousands of secrets, simple to play but hard to master, everything is excessively badass and more!

- Oldschool spirit and art: super gory, amazing sprites, pixels and explosions everywhere, cool and chunky 2D and 3D effects, doesn't care about your feelings, funny profanities, and more!

- Superfunny and immensely satisfying

- Picking only the best of the best of old school games and mechanics and enriching them!

- Running on one of the best game engines ever, IMPROVED!

- Cool and badass character, enemies and settings

- Very immersive and catchy, also I love the soundtracks, very cool!

- Weapons are just spectacular, they feel super powerful and also realistic. The weapon you choose to use in a determinated situation matters 100%. They're all well differentiated and super funny to use. And they're even bind to the right keys!!! 1 Melee, 2 Pistol, 3 Shotgun, 4 Machinegun... that's class guys.

- Bowling Bombs, the "ace", protagonist weapon of the game (check the story to understand why) are very original and never seen. They have more depth than I thought on the first play, the "Bombardier" mode made me understand how they interact with each other or with objects. And guess what? They're super funny and satisfying to use. Big surprise!

- Just buy this game and check its quality by yourself, you'll see why all the hype!

CONS

- If you're severely mentally disabled and have no taste at all and also can't play sh*t, you may dislike the game.

- The devs are super humble even after developing historical games. Oh wait, that's not a bad thing. Oops.

3D Realms went back in time to bring us the kind of games that made gamers exist in the first place. The kind of games that you still play and enjoy more than 20 years after their realease. I strongly hope they're going to continue on this path of "Less shit and more fun" that was abandoned a long time ago. And I also hope others are going to follow their example. Jesus guys, you can sell a game for half the price of a modern AAA, with a tenth of the people requested for AAA games, developing it in less time, focusing on funnier and more important features, and earn the 600% you would normally earn! That's just a smart way to develop games!

To conclude, I'm waiting with great expectations the full release, meanwhile I'll enjoy the demo! And I'll also pray for Blood III... now they can bring it in all its glory to its fans, unlike Blood II...

Go 3D Realms, bring Good Old Games back to Us!

[b]Ion Maiden[/b] - та самая игра, которая изначально была прелюдией к неудачной [b]Bombshell[/b]. Но в итоге видим следующее: игра получилась охренительной, а тот урод, получившийся на выходе у Interceptor, должен даваться игрокам в подарок. И то, за это ещё приплачивать должны.

[h1]Много, но в то же время и мало...[/h1]
[b]Preview Campaign[/b] я прошёл ещё на версии для Good Old Games, заботливо скачанной с Rutracker. Но она меня зацепила. Геймплеем это всё тот же старый Дючок. Стреляешь, когда думаешь, но не думаешь, когда стреляешь. Только успевай стрелять / раскидывать бомбы / подбирать аптечки / снова стрелять. На те три уровня, которые есть в превью, авторы не поленились добавить уйму секретов: на одном первом уровне их только ДВАДЦАТЬ. [b]КУДА ВЫ ИХ ЗАПИХАЛИ-ТО, А?![/b]
Оружия тоже приличное количество для демо-версии. Тот самый револьвер [b]Loverboy[/b], стреляющий шесть раз по три выстрела. Дробовик [b]Dispencer[/b] - внешне напоминает гранатомёт из классического [b]Shadow Warrior[/b]. [b]SMG-9000[/b] - это когда хочется щекотки... вашим врагам, самое бесполезное по урону оружие. [b]Миниган[/b], из которого толком даже пострелять не дали. И конечно же, наш фаворит, [b]резиновая дубинка[/b], бьющая током. Хотя, как так получается, что резина ток может проводить, а?
Геймдизайн тоже неплох: вот перед нами база GDF, улицы с небольшим перегрузом неона на глаз, канализация с прилегающей к ней станцией метро, авеню с магазинами и парк, в котором происходит битва с единственным боссом на данный момент. Вроде что-то новенькое, какой-то лёгкий налёт киберпанка и урбанизма, но в то же время всё это так знакомо, как Hollywood Holocaust.

[h1]Voidpoint и 3D Realms, позвольте задать пару вопросов...[/h1]
Почему? Почему оптимизация в вашем совместном продукте, мягко говоря, не очень? В игре используется не оригинальный Build Engine, а форк под названием eDuke32. При таком наполнении игра должна работать как по маслу, ведь оригинальный Дючок из под этого форка работает как по маслу.
Почему такое небольшое разнообразие противников? Я видел всего лишь... культиста, парня в маске черепа с дробовиком, ещё одного культиста в красном плаще (механикусы из сорокатысячника, привет), какие-то головы на механических лапках (на этот раз привет передаю сервочерепам из того же сорокатысячника). Финального босса кампании в качестве отдельного класса противников не рассматриваю, это просто босс.
И последний вопрос... [b]ПОЧЕМУ ВЫ НЕ ДАЛИ ПОСТРЕЛЯТЬ ИЗ МИНИГАНА?! ДА ВАШУ Ж МАТЬ![/b]

40826324.review:
Absolutely adored this preview of the campaign, there is something special here. 

Has that feel of Build era games, but with the added insight from how games have progressed in the last 20 odd years. Fun and interesting level design, and crunchy flairs with attention to the little details. The graphical tweaks and upgrades are a delight. The music is a strong highlight, especially if you like demoscene era tracks.

I also appreciate this version of the Bombshell character design, feels particularly badass.

All up, a (currently) short but very enjoyable experience. Looking forward to the full release!

40794712.review:
When Microsoft crudely hammered its way into the console scene in 2001 with Halo it sent the FPS as a genre in a downward spiral to mediocrity as developers garrotted everything we knew and loved to make them work on a console with a joypad. 

Narrow FOV, limited weapons, forced crosshairs, health regen and poor level design were all part of this cancerous approach that unfortunately went terminal in 2007 with COD4 resulting in many even going so far as to state that gaming 'died' in 2007, since then quality FPS have been very few and far between.

Others will have commented in greater detail of the wizardry of the enhanced build engine that runs IM but for me the thing that makes IM so good is how it FEELS, the guns FEEL right, the level design FEELS right and most importantly the movement FEELS right.

Having only sampled Ion Maiden I can say it is the very definition of having to look back to look forward and I very much look forward to what we're going to get later on this year.

Aquí los niveles TAMBIÉN son al estilo de la vieja escuela, enrevesados, bien diseñados, "run & gun" de verdad, y decenas de secretos. Ni que decir que son los mejores mapas que he visto hechos en la Build engine en mi vida (y no he visto pocos).

40791769.review:
3D Realms is working on a new shooter based on the famous Bulid engine in 2018 - as if this alone would not already be enough to stun me, Ion Maiden is astonishingly good.

It looks like the game I dreamed future games could look like in 1996.

The cyberpunk-design, soundtrack and atmosphere are beautifully old-school. The gameplay, the humour, the one-liners, the gore – all of it fits so perfectly well together. Ion Maiden doesn't care to copy the gameplay of Duke Nukem 3D and Shadow Warrior - it aims to be their true successor. And it is on the best way to achieve that.


There is a To-Do-List for the developers though:

[list]
[*]The level-design bleeds vitality, but lacks interactivity (for example: glass cannot be shattered)
[*]The gunplay doesn't feel perfect yet (I'm looking at you, clip size of the SMG-9000)
[/list]

But those are trifles...

[b]Thank you for making this game, Voidpoint! Keep going![/b]

40775235.review:
Ion Maiden is an FPS featuring sprawling level design littered with upwards of twenty secrets per map, a protagonist who constantly throws out cheesy one-liners (reminiscient of Duke Nukem or Lo Wang), and fast paced movement with multiple guns which feel really fun to use and easily gib enemies. As such, it's an obvious throwback to games like Shadow Warrior Classic, Blood or the before-mentioned Douk. This should be enough to get you interested immediately if you like first person shooters.

The only obvious problems right now have to do with the fact that it's a work in progress, and so presently it only features one preview campaign comprised of two moderately-sized levels, only a couple of weapons (out of which some require slightly more damage tweaks), not enough voice work, and above all, an AI which is not accurate and aggressive enough to provide you with a sufficient challenge. Even on the highest available difficulty you'll not really be tested and end up with lots of armor, ammo and available portable medkits. There's also the problem of technical issues.

Ion Maiden runs off of a modified Build Engine, which is now around twenty years old, and as such it has a tendency to hiccup weirdly whenever something more demanding (like explosions revealing and shifting parts of the level around) happens, which is incredibly annoying, throws your aiming off and screws up your flow. Even after the patch I'd say that this is the biggest problem and is inexcusable for a first person shooter, so here's hoping the developers work on fixing it.

However even with the above problems, and even if it's not something you're willing to spend money on presently, what is there is still incredibly fun to play. The project is definitely worth following if you're a fan of old-school shooters.

40769892.review:
Ion Maiden is technically a prequel to Bombshell, set in a futuristic cyberpunk-esque city called Neo DC. The setting heavily reminds me of Shrapnel City from Duke Nukem 1 and already I'm in love with the game. The level design and graphics ooze mid-90's charm and the level of detail is insane given it's using such an old engine. I especially love the colour palette of the game, which seems to focus on a mix of red and blue (possibly to symbolically reflect the heroine's police background). It's definitely on par if not surpassing the detail seen in Blood. The game also pulls some rather impressive scripted sequences that wouldn't look out of place in a Call of Duty game (albeit with the graphics of a mid-90's game engine), giving the game a very high explosive "Michael Bay" feel that I absolutely love.

Scope is really the key word of Ion Maiden. Instead of going for a linear "level to level" approach, the game is structured into multiple zones (with the preview campaign having only one zone) which could be considered the equivalent of an episode, except in this case you can go back and forth between the levels as you see fit, similar to games like Quake 2 and Half-Life. The game will warn you when you're about to enter a part of the zone that closes off the rest behind you though by warning you that there are still secrets left to find in the area if you haven't found all of them, a useful tip for OCD players like myself who want to find every secret before moving on and very much appreciated. This makes each zone feel like one big hub of levels, and given the size of some levels (especially level 2 of the preview campaign is an enormous level with impressively large buildings), it's safe to say the game's scope will be pretty big.

The game's weapon selection consists of what you'd expect. A melee weapon (Shelly's electric baton), a revolver (the Loverboy), a shotgun (the Disperser) and an automatic SMG (the SMG-9000) in addition to Shelly's signature bowling bombs (essentially heat-seeking grenades). All of the weapons feel really satisfying to fire, and i don't really have any complaints about them. The sound effects are really good as well and give that "oomph" feeling that I love about oldschool shooters.

The game definitely does a great job at feeling like a lost game from 1995 that's been polished up. Shelly's character portrait constantly sits in the lower left corner, looking left and right while also becoming increasingly bloody and damaged as you receive damage, similar to games like Doom and Quake, a small detail that further emphasizes the game's mid-90's tone. Her one-liners are cool and ooze confidence and charisma and I'm happy to see Shelly's voice actress from Bombshell return here and given she doesn't really have to do any dramatic acting, she does a great job just spouting one-liners, which I think fits the character more than the amount of dialogue she was given in Bombshell.

 Control-wise the game controls well, although some people have reported issues with the mouse aiming (a common issue with build engine games). If you have played other build engine games, you'll feel right at home in this game although interestingly the game does not have any inventory system like other Build games. You have an inventory for medkits but pretty much nothing else, which makes me wonder if there will be one in the full version.

The soundtrack is done entirely as mod music, which explains the game's low file size, but is generally really well done, sounding somewhat industrial and techno'y and perfectly fits the game's aesthetic.

Now to the negatives... the game is really unoptimized. Severely unoptimized even. Running in OpenGL mode, even with some of the performance tweaks the devs have listed on the Steam forums I ran into severe hitching/stuttering and the framerate going into slideshow territory repeatedly during gameplay, especially during heavily scripted sequences or just looking around certain parts of the levels (particurarily level 2). Running the game with the Classic renderer fixed most of these issues but the game still runs somewhat badly. I would attribute this to the fact the preview campaign is essentially a beta though and hope they will make it more stable in the full version. I also experienced the game crashing repeatedly on level 2 after playing for a while, though the devs are working on a fix for it.

Considering the game is still early in development all I can say is that I'm really looking forward to the full version! So far it's a really enjoyable experience, and it's shaping up to be one hell of a shooter!

40766677.review:
Ion Maiden ist ein 90er Retro FPS vom Hause 3D Realms und das Prequel von "Bombshell".

Die Grafik ist einfach für mich ein deftiger Nostalgie Flash! Mit der guten alten Build Engine sieht das Spiel einfach richtig aus. Aus der Engine haben die Entwickler meiner Meinung nach alles was nur noch möglich war rausgeholt. Selbst die Sprites sehen richtig gut aus. Alleine schon deswegen riesiges Lob an die Entwickler.

Das Gameplay wie man es aus den alten 90er Shooter kennt. Waffen sammeln, Secrets finden und mit diversen Türkarten Türen öffnen. Was man natürlich nicht vergessen darf die rasanten Baller Orgien die man von solchen Spielen einfach gewöhnt ist. Alleine die Bewegungsgeschwindigkeit der Figur ist ein Traum! Da können sich eigentlich neue Spiele sich wirklich eine Scheibe abschneiden, weil dieses rumgegurke in dem neuen Spielen ist einfach nur grässlich! Das Spiel ist zurzeit noch im EA und bietet eine sehr gute "Preview Campaign" mit zwei verschienen Leveln und einem Boss.

Alles in allem ist Ion Maiden für jeden Fan der alten Build Engine ein absolutes MUSS! Wenn man das Spielmenü sieht schwebt man schon im siebten Himmel und fühlt sich einfach 20 Jahre zurück versetzt. Also eine klare Kaufemphelung für den Preis aufjedenfall!

40668833.review:
Ion Maiden... Внезапная и прекрасная Дева.

Шутеры так называемого "олдскула" давно прекратили выходить на рынке игроиндустрии в своем классическом виде (нелинейные карты, тактические возможности, выверенная механика, разнобразие). В последние годы были лишь жалкие попытки завлечь старых игроков пиксельной графикой (два шикарнейших исключения - Dusk и Amid Evil), имея при этом совершенно недопустимые для шутера вещи, такие как процедурная генерация уровней и одинаковые игровые элементы (враги и оружие), малое количество интересных ситуаций и т.д. Все же последующие после середины 90-х игры не могли похвастаться грамотными схемами своих предшественников. Вспоминая так называемую "Могучую тройку движка Build" (Duke Nukem 3D, Shadow Warrior и Blood), от всего этого делается еще паршивее - неужели люди не понимают, в чем секрет хорошего шутера?

Оказалось, еще как понимают. Ion Maiden, разрабатываемая компанией Voidpoint (под издательством 3D Realms) просто игнорирует все эти 20 с лишним лет и продолжает традицию хороших шутеров там, где эти традиции остановились. Здесь мы имеем: 6 видов оружия для определенной ситуации (в полном релизе оружия будет еще больше и у каждого появится альтернативный огонь), несколько видов врагов с разными атаками и разным поведением (опять же, их армия пополнится новыми видами), продуманный, комплексный дизайн всех пяти имеющихся карт, грамотное расположение ресурсов и противников на этих картах, прекрасный визуальный стиль с легким налетом киберпанка а также одного босса, победить которого весьма непросто. Игра также вводит совершенно нетипичные для таких игр и грамотно распределенные механики: перезарядку оружия и точечные повреждения (стрельба в голову наносит трехкратный урон). За этот час с небольшим у вас не будет даже мысли о том, что где-то схалтурили или недоработали, все идет так, как нужно в хороших играх. Уже сейчас у меня ни на секунду не возникает мысли о том, что полная версия игры может быть чем-либо испорчена. Поэтому прямо сейчас я говорю: "Могучей тройки Build" больше нет. Да здравствует "Могучая четверка Build"! 

Браво, Voidpoint, так держать, и удачи с разработкой!

40662694.review:
Analisis actual: Preview Campaign

LO RECOMIENDO, PERO AHORA MISMO NO, mas adelante hablo de esto.

Lo llamo " Analisis actual " sencillamente porque Ion Maiden está todavia en desarrollo. Voy a deglosar poco a poco mi analisis con forme se vaya ampliando la propuesta de Ion Maiden.

En primer lugar, Ion Maiden es el sucesor espíritual de Duke Nukem...vaya, son los mismos creadores y todo xD.

El detalles es que en este. se respiran todos los elementos clasicos del bueno de Duke Nukem, shooter en primera persona frenetico, comentarios del mismo protagonista ( en este caso, una mujer de cuyo nombre es Shelly "Bombshell" Harrison,...exacto, la misma chica del videojuego Bombshell ) y el sentido del humor que transmite Duke tambien lo hace Shelly ...pero no tan bestia como Duke.

Jugablemente es una delicia, es rápdido, los controles son sencillos y la dificultad..al principio tiene una curvatura de difitulad bastante alta a pesar de que haya empezado en normal...luego conforme se estabiliza mi munición y el ahazgo de estas ya todo se hace mas llevadero.

Ahora lo siguiente, el estado actual de Ion Maiden solo se compone de 2 escenarios de modo historia...me llevó aproximadamente una hora y poco mas en completarlo...de momento no recomiendo comprarlo hasta que que hayan engrosado el estado actual de Ion Maiden...de momento yo estoy contento con las bases del juego, estoy esperando con ansias el resto del modo historia, ver lo que es capaz la comunidad de Modders para Steam Workshop y el modo multijugador.

40642367.review:
This review is for the initial preview campaign released in Early Access.

What a surprise this turned out to be!  Bombshell, a top-down action RPG, released a few years back and it receieved a cold reception, with low exposure by games media and mediocre sales to boot.  Before release, word of an FPS prequel for the Build engine was teased, and a couple screenshots were thrown onto forums and twitter.  Those screenshots are what perked my ears.  I silently waited for years, checking periodically on progress, and now the tree bears its fruit, albeit not ripe yet.

Pros:
-Solid core gameplay mechanics with clear vision in mind, bringing forth nostalgia but also a fresh experience.

-Gorgeous sprite-work and textures powered by an upgraded Build engine, giving it a very authentic vibe.

-Shelly has character, as any Build engine protagonist should, and I'm excited to hear all of her lines in the final product.  Plus, cute.

-Secrets out the ass (seriously, there are many more than you would expect).  They definitely require you to think outside the box, and you are absolutely rewarded for it.

-Great sound design with room to improve, killer soundtrack (can't wait to hear more of this especially).

-Level design is very non-linear and engaging, paced well.  It's a blast to explore and check out all of the little things.

-Overall tight package for an early access game.  Meant to tease for now, please you later.

Cons:
-Enemy variety is lacking, and they need more sounds for lurking, death, and pain.  But this IS a preview model game, so this will very likely be fleshed out by release.

-HUD is simple, but functional, could use more flair as an option.

-OpenGL renderer is choppy as hell, software is smoother.  Again, will likely be more optimized in the future.

-UI in the save/load screen needs more polish.

-Levels within a zone have a seamless transition, but I feel some sort of partition (level announcement, map name appears on screen, maybe a message) would be nice, even if it only showed up once upon moving from one part to the next, while backtracking could remain seamless.

-$20 is a steep price for a package this small, and considering this was technically $3 when bundled as a bonus for Bomdshell, it's a pill to swallow in its current state.  

In a nutshell, this is a 90's Build engine game ripped from an alternate timeline, a companion to classics such as Duke 3D and Shadow Warrior, and an obvious labor of love from a team with passion and dedication.  I expect good things to come from this title, and I encourage classic fans to buy it now, and newbies to buy it when it releases.

40630804.review:
Of the throwback FPS games I've seen around, this is probably my favourite.

Other retro FPS games seem to only have a surface-level understanding of what made the original FPS games great. People look at things like fast movement, health packs, non-linear level design, and think that's as far as it goes. Ion Maiden separates itself by deeply understanding what works, and integrating it into a solid core gameplay.

As such the movement feels fast but satisfying, gunplay is loud but also punchy, level design is complex but logical. I could go through a list of old-school FPS trappings, but to do so would almost miss the point. Taken as a whole Ion Maiden is a great modern game.

Also the bowling bombs are really fun to use. That helps.

40629313.review:
[b]--- Cette critique concerne uniquement l'Early Access et la Campagne Preview ---[/b]

[h1]Come get more[/h1]
Ion Maiden, dans sa version Early Access, c'est un peu comme fêter l'anniversaire d'un pote qu'on avait oublié depuis longtemps, surtout depuis qu'il avait réalisé des trucs pas très nets. C'est un peu comme Sonic Mania : le retour aux sources mais avec juste ce qu'il faut de modernité pour que le jeu soit agréable aujourd'hui. Et justement, puisqu'on parle de source...

[h1]Damn, I'm still good[/h1]
Conçu avec le très vieux moteur [b]Build[/b] de [b]Dukem Nukem 3D[/b] boosté aux hormones, le jeu reprend donc tout ce qui faisait le charme de DN3D même si dans la version disponible à la sortie, il y a un certain manque d'interactivité avec le décor -on peut toujours interagir avec des éléments mais beaucoup moins. Ce qui fait en revanche la grande, très grande force d'Ion Maiden, c'est [b]l'ouverture de ses niveaux.[/b]

C'est bien simple : les niveaux, gigantesques, sont séparés en plusieurs zones dans lesquelles on peut revenir à tout moment (tant que l'on a pas terminé le niveau en question). Limitation de Build oblige, il y a un très court temps de chargement (accompagné d'une sauvegarde automatique) lorsque l'on passe d'une zone à une autre, mais on constate avec plaisir que tout ce qu'on y a fait (massacres, passages secrets ouvert) est exactement à sa place. L'interconnexion des zones permet aussi d'accéder de plusieurs façons possibles à son objectif. Il y a régulièrement deux, trois voire plus de façons possibles de franchir un obstacle, ce qui ouvre donc la voie au [b]gameplay émergeant[/b].

[h1]It's between you and me, you one eye freak ![/h1]
Cette courte campagne de deux gros niveaux plus un boss est chouette mais reste très courte. Le studio a promis l'arrivée des outils de modding et l'ouverture du Steam Workshop est prévue, ce qui pavera la voie à, on l'espère, un paquet de trucs passionnants en attendant la véritable campagne du jeu final.

Verdict :
Duke Nukem devrait prendre des notes sur Ion Maiden / 10.

40622385.review:
Ion Maiden is what Gearbox failed to acheive with their 2016 release of Duke Nukem World Tour - the return legendary Build engine.

Ion Maiden, isn't a love letter to the classic FPS genre, it would be a cop out in saying so. It is such more than that, and in a great way. It has some issues, but for the price and excitement of a classic genre to return, to me, seems a worthy price of admission. 

For your consideration, the Build engine has seem some stuff, like 'Nam thousand yard stare stuff. There has been many releases on the Build engine, with amazing titles such as Duke Nukem 3D & Blood and not so great stuff like Redneck Rampage and WWII GI.

Ion Maiden is a release that pushes the Build to its limits with it's beautiful open vistas, mingy basements and inspiring cityscapes, like a Hollywood Holocaust on [i]Nuke[/i]. To be blunt, the level design is primarily the best reason for this curiosity, and anyone who likes to uncover secrets will find much to do in these couple of preview levels. It also does a lot of great level design checks, such as often being able to see it, means you can get there - or levels eventually returning back to a previous area and creating a believable and full circle environment.

Weapons are very satisfying, which is essential for any first person shooter, you'll find a revolver that asks the question Do I feel lucky? Well, do ya, punk? The SMG is pretty cool and does enough damage to ensure it's worth, and the shotgun folds chairs, period. Can't forget the Bowling Ball bombs, but well get to that. Every weapon has a reload animation, but I never felt that it impeded combat. Especially considering how quick everything is, combat and pacing, the reloads feel  tolerable. A few frames at most, and you can reload whenever you like.

Music is good, pretty great stuff - but it's quite short for how long the levels are. You're gonna hear the same loops a lot, which might make some people get annoyed. I will be honest, it got to me towards the end a bit, especially while hunting for the [b]33[/b] secrets!

There are one-liners. Nothing over the top, but I felt they repeated too much, especially when you're blowing up everyone with the bombs. Theres a few eye-rollers but nothing that will make you uninstall. Especially because there's an off/on button but a slider would've been great. But that's probably an option unavailable for Build.


Enemies are a mix of hitscan and seeable shots. Their range doesnt seem infinite, so you wont find any Tibetan chaingunners yodelling lead towards you from another planet or anything. But I found getting plinked occasionally. I could be wrong on this. 

BUT, whoever decided to have -not- headcrabs BLOOD hands or whatever little enemies, bad move! Who the hell loves fighting small hit boxes? augh so annoying and you'll definitely find these whenever theres a vent around or an ambush waiting to happen

Criticisms: 

Reboundable Quick Save/Load - Common u goobers! Definitely an oversight. 

Music isn't catchy or lengthy enough to meet the level size.

Unoptimization? Getting crazy frame drops on a 1050ti, especially in combat, seems pretty whack.

Keycards on the ground are quite small, this might not be a ball breaker for the pros and veterans of small detail, but a corpse falls on a key, or in a key finds itself in the shade, I feel that I have a big chance of missing it and then wandering around wondering where I goofed up. 

Item placement needs some TLC, or whiskey. Found areas where there was lots of ammo and health, and then large chunks where there were a lotta baddies and no ammo and health. Seems like oversight or rookie mistakes. I just dont want that to be a trend.

The tracking/seeking on the bowling ball bombs can break. Example: I threw a bomb and it spun around the cyborg soldier indefinetly and was pretty anticlimatic. Rectified by just throwing another. I've also thrown bombs that just fall through some sectors (particularly at the back end of the first level). Needs an alternative fire to explode them on command, much like a pipe bomb.

That's all I really have to say, for a few hours to complete everything in the review, its a real feel good trip down memory lane for those who want that, but it also stands on its own merits and brings you great level design, gun umph and old school slaughter that many throwbacks fail to fully grasp.

Shine on you crazy Ion, lets make this one for the books. 

Come Get S- errr you know what to expect!

40604806.review:
Yes, it's good


Ok maybe I need to say something else. You like old school first person shooters? And by that I mean actual old school first person shooters from the 90s and not some indie pseudo-retro FPS with procedural levels instead of good level design? Then this game is for you. And when I say good level design I mean really good level design, the kind of design you used to find in games like Doom, Duke Nukem 3D or Shadow Warrior. You'll have to explore and search for keycards and secrets behind every corner, and they're not the kind of secrets you find humping walls pressing E like a madman but the kind of secrets that will make you think "how the hell am I supposed to reach that place I see in the distance?" or "I wonder if something will happen if I do this".

Early access let's you play a preview campaign that will not be part of the final release but does a pretty good job showing you everything you need to know about how the final release will be. It's short but really well made if you can ignore some optimization problems that are really hard to understand considering the fact that the games that used this engine before Ion Maiden ran on a 486 more than 20 years ago. It looks great, like what I imagine these games would look like if they didn't stop using this engine back in the day, same style but higher level of detail.

I recommend this game right now if you're ready to pay the price for a very short but great experience with more to come in about 6 months. They promise a lot more when the complete game is finally here but we'll have to wait and see.

I don't write reviews often, but I feel the need to write a review for this.  First of all, let me say this:

If you like 90s shooters, get this game immediately.

Seriously, this game is really good.  There are so many secrets to find in each of the (currently 2) levels, 33 secrets in total.  The weapons are currently limited, but they handle great.  Personally, my favorite weapons are the Loverboy, the disperser, and the bowling bombs.

The devs are insidious with their placement of secrets.  Some secrets are easy to find, others are hidden pretty well.  Others are easy to spot, but getting to them requires some platforming, some of which I found difficult, though that's probably just me being really rusty at 90s shooters.  There's a certain secret that really caught me off-guard, really made me laugh my ass off.  The devs know which one.  Well played, you magnificent bastards.

The only cons I can think of at the moment are that it's not finished, but that's really not a con.  The bowling bombs only mode is pretty great, really helps you get more time out of the game, especially if you try to 100% it.

For the devs, I offer this:  continue the "Bombshell" so that it's more in line with this.  If you do that, you'll strike gold.  Love you guys, can't wait for the full game!

40596771.review:
I owe a lot to Ken Silverman and 3d Realms- the Build Engine and subsequently Duke 3d are the things that got me into game design. The moment I saw this, I knew it was going to be magic. I wasn't wrong.

They've done some wonderful things with this old engine and made a preview for a game I now greatly anticipate. It's very fast paced while still having some large levels for a Build Engine game. Enemies are interesting and keep you on your toes, and some of the weapons are pretty neat (bowling bombs for example). The extra game modes are also a fun way to mix it up.

I didn't have many issues, however while I have a relatively beefy computer, there are still some random hiccups here and there- a bit surprising because the engine has such a small footprint, and there are some strange collision issues with some solid sprite-based objects and platforms. Other than those couple of issues this game is very recommended.

This game looks like it could have been released in the Duke Nukem 3D area, around 1996. For this game, that's a good thing because it really manages to give you that great old first person shooter action.

However, the performance of the game is poor. I don't mean low framerates, I reach about 150+. But even with those high framerates, the game doesn't feel smooth. It's difficult to discribe, but with 150 frames per seconds it sometimes feels like 10 frames per second. There is a topic about performance optimalisation in the Steam discussions section because more people have issues with performance. I tried all the optimalisations mentioned in the topic, but it didn't help. 

I sadly do not recommend Ion Maiden with those performance issues. However, if those performance issues get solved I will definitely recommend it.

By the way I tried this game on two machines, both had performance issues:
- Laptop with I7 4710HQ, 8GB RAM, GTX850M, SSD
- Desktop with AMD Phenom II X6 T1045, 8GB RAM, R9 270, HDD

40560294.review:
[quote][i]Neo D.C. Stylish. Neon illuminated. Deadly.[/i][/quote]

[h1]Build Engine (or pointless intro)[/h1]
More than 2 decades after engine release we get ourselves a new Build engine game. A game that has to compete with [i]Blood, Duke Nukem 3D[/i] and [i]Shadow Warrior[/i]. A game that has to surpass gameplay-wise each and every predecessor or at least reach the same level of quality. Old school FPS games are in demand as triple-A releases barely scratch an itch for some fast-paced hardcore mindless action with badass soundtrack, while indies try to saturate the market with mixed success. So, when you hear [i]New build engine game in 2018[/i] you get hyped. But instead of shouting [i]"Build Engine. 2018. Old School. F-ing cool. Buy Now."[/i], let's calm down and find out, whether it's something worth [i]shooting around[/i].

[i]The following wall of text is about preview campaign (or should we call it preview Zone). The review [b]may[/b] get updated upon full release. tl;dr version, as usual, at the bottom.[/i]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Movement.[/b] As every other old-school game it is fast as it should be. Whether it is tight dimly lit corridor or a vast open street, you'll be strafing, running and gunning. And it's damn good, as good as it was back in '90s.
[*][b]Guns.[/b] There are 5 as of now: melee shock baton; triple-barrel revolver called [i]The Loverboy[/i]; shotgun called [i]The Disperser[/i]; sub-machine gun [i]SMG-9000[/i] and [i]Bowling Bombs[/i]. Melee weapon is more of a nostalgic nod than a viable weapon; revolver, shotgun and sub-machine gun are your typical weapons with reloading (controversial design decision for some) slapped on'em; but bowling bombs are awesome homing balls of exploding fun. To each their own, but sub-machine gun felt powerless and useless in every scenario except maybe final boss.
[*][b]Enemies.[/b] Currently there are 4 and 1 boss. 3 enemies are you generic badies with shotgun/sub-machine gun/crossbow, 1 is spider-like melee creature and the boss is a mech with chaingun and rockets. None are challenging, none are exceptionally unique. That said, right now, enemy variety is underwhelming.
[*][b]Game and difficulty modes.[/b] There are 3 difficulty modes and sadly they are:
1. The easiest.
2. Easier.
3. Easy.
Some may argue that the difficulty is okay, but for me playing on Ion Maiden's Hard was like playing something between Doom's "Hey, not too rough" and "Hurt me plenty". Running out of ammo is never a challenge, getting your health below 50 is never a problem.
What's more interesting is [i]Bombardier Trial[/i] game mode (unlocked after finishing the campaign), in which your max health is capped at 25 and you're given unlimited bowling bomb supply. But again, it's hardly teeth grinding challenge.
[*][b]Levels.[/b] The campaign is divided into 2 big levels which are comprised of a smaller "sub-levels". Most of the time, there are multiple ways to traverse through, multiple shortcuts that can be opened and exploration doesn't feel tedious or tacked on. The itself campaign can be finished in a hour or so.
[*][b]Secrets.[/b] Glory to the secrets. It's less of mashing "E" on every surface and more of observe/think/navigate/overcome. Hidden switches, hidden platforms, hidden breakable object, time-based triggers, platforming sections - secrets are great. Reaching the end level switch and getting slapped with [i]"you are now missing 10 secrets..."[/i] winds you up. [i]"Wow, how the hell did I miss those?"[/i] and you replay the level only to get [i]"you are now missing 4 secrets"[/i].
[*][b]Replay value.[/b] Bombardier Trial and more than 30 secrets to find is enough reason to replay the campaign once if not several times.
[/list]

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
In short, the visuals are glorious. The sprite work is notch: the weapons, the enemies, the pickable items are distinct and detailed. The environments are filled with little objects, details and vary greatly. There is never a feel, that you're going through the same room over and over again. The amount of textures and decorations allows to reuse them without player constantly noticing it.

[h1]Sound[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Soundtrack.[/b] 3-4 setpieces, that currently are present in the release, are rather forgettable and unintrusive; nothing to write home about.
[*][b]Sounds.[/b] Guns, enemies, ambient sound are generally okay, again, nothing to write home about.
[*][b]One-liner Badassery.[/b] At this point, it's hard to judge whether the protagonist will be able to deliver as there aren't many lines present in the campaign. "Ka-boom", "Holy shit", "I spray, you pray" are just a few examples of what there currently is.
[/list]

[h1]tl;dr checklist[/h1]
Pros:
[list]
[*]Fast-paced action. No "arena with 6 enemy max" crap.
[*]Vast levels to explore with keycard hoarding.
[*]Environment detalization is great (for 2 decade old engine that is).
[*]Secrets that are actual secrets.
[*]Additional game mode increases replay value.
[/list]
Neutrals:
[list]
[*]Guns are pretty standard.
[*]Hard difficulty is easy.
[*]Unintrusive but forgettable soundtrack.
[/list]
Cons:
[list]
[*]Currently lacks enemy variety.
[*]Rather short.
[/list]

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
[i][b]Ion Maiden[/b][/i] has a lot of potential. It delivers detailed environments, fast-paced action, semi non-linear levels, keycard hoarding and brings back actual [i]SECRETS[/i]. But current Preview Campaign lacks in enemy variety, difficulty and sound design quality. If you've played every other Build Engine classic and you are itching for more right here and right now no matter how short the experience may be, then go ahead and buy [i][b]Ion Maiden[/b][/i].
Otherwise, hold you robotic horses and wait for the full release.

40557916.review:
Is this game worth getting now? Yes

Ion Maiden is essentially the spiritual sequel to Duke Nukem 3D, the classic Build-engine style game and uses the very same engine, but modified and modernized.

Currently, as of this review, you can only play the first part of 7 proposed chapters of the game. I beat the game on Normal difficulty, and "Bombardier Mode" on Normal difficulty, which is a game mode where you only play with bowling bombs and have a mximum of 25 health. Both modes for chapter 1 I beat blind in roughly 1:40:00 (an hour and forty minutes).

While this may seem steep to some for 20 USD, the full game I feel will be very much worth it, if what we have to go on so far is any indication.

If you've ever played a Build-engine game before, this game is like riding a bike, you never really forget how to do it. The level layouts are unique and large, the gun-play is fantastic (the disperser is seriously on the level of satisfying as that of DOOM II's Super Shotgun, yes, it really is) and the difficulty itself is actually really balanced, not too hard, not too easy, just right.

My only real cons are that Shelly herself has very few lines, and often repeats the same two lines pretty often, so you don't really get a feel for the character, and the enemy variety is particularly low, there are roughly 4 enemy types and a boss that repeat themselves throughout the whole level, while this is not out of the ordinary for a Build-engine game, without the subsequent chapters to play, it does make one yearn for more variety in enemies and powerups.

Overall, would absolutely recommend, Voidpoint and 3DRealms have something special on their hands if done right.

MINUS:
- short preview campaign (it's not a real deal but 2 hours is not much time for a campaign, rather for a demo),

OPTIONAL:
* seamless coming from one level to a next one (it's not actually a minus but in old shooters (DN3D, Doom, Quake) a next level was loading up; here we have the 'Loading' description only),

All in all, this game is worthy any penny (cent). It's done VERY well!

The game definitly needs some work though, and Early Access was a pretty smart choice.

Awesome Retro FPS action

Over the top Duke Nukem style humor

Cons:

40548495.review:
It's good.
It's REALLY good.

BUT

There's a lot of problems, and a lot of things that are weirdly inferior to older build engine games.  Hopefully there's still development looking at feedback because as a huge duke3d fan i'd imagine a lot of other fans will notice as well (which will probably be the primary audience of this game)

The Bad:

1.  Reloading in a game like this is ANNOYING, it's "acceptable" but it would have been a lot more fun without it
2.  There's a huge lack of interactive objects, none of the drink machines, coffee makers, etc work, it may sound minor but duke3d was so good because of a lot of little things adding up and it really did make the world feel more "real".
3.  The toilets dissapointed me, you had the perfect chance to invoke nostalgia by having a guy on it when you open the door but instead there's just a line of dudes behind each door standing up with shotguns :/
4.  The mirrors dont work.  This stood out quite a bit, as they DID in duke3d.
5.  Armor shards are super hard to see
6.  you get stuck on geometry more than in older build games, not sure why, i think some things have hitboxes at weird angles, the enemies get stuck all the time like this too
7.  ammo seems a little TOO scarce early on for the number of shots enemies take....my aim was pretty good, didn't miss much, and i still found my ammo running pretty low most of the early game.  After you get your second gun though you're pretty much a walking armory/pharmacy (i had 6 spare medkits when i reached the boss and i didn't even find many of the secrets)
8.  the ladders jerk you around quite a bit when you transition up or down, i know it's done for the room over room trick but the transition is pretty jarring sometimes.

The good:

1. The voiceovers are pretty good
2. Overall I liked the graphics, a bit rough in some spots though.
3. Aside from the reloading issue the speed and flow of gameplay was solid.

40548306.review:
Already completed the preview campaign and I am eagerly waiting for more. 

Not once have I posted some sort of review, but this game is something else. Personally, I was never brought up on 90s FPS games and I came to the scene pretty late. I started with DooM and worked my way up from there all the while playing countless hours of many DooM WADs that are out there on Moddb. 

First off, this game is a perfect reimagining of the 90s FPS genre, it has brought back the Build engine which has powered some other really good games such as Blood, Duke Nukem 3D and Shadow Warrior. 
The weapons that have been added so far feel absolutely amazing, and each has it's own purpose and is to be used for the right enemy at the right time for maximum efficiency. 
The enemy types are quite varied and you are able to dodge their attacks if you are quick enough, all the enemies are balanced for an enjoyable gameplay so you feel good when killing them from all the bullets you have unloaded into them. 
Gunplay for this game is extremely fun and fluid and you will probably eventually run out of bullets for some weapons if you aren't on point with your accuracy (I personally played with no aim assist whatsoever). There's still plenty of ammo drops laying around and you can get ammo drops from enemies that you kill.
The secrets in Ion Maiden are quite rewarding, considering that you actually look around and explore every nook and cranny, or you can just simply constantly press the use key on every surface you come across.
The artstyle and atmosphere of this game is absolutely staggering, every inch of every level shows the passion and care that the map maker put into making it and it pushes you to explore all the halls and rooms that may possibly lead you to a secret...
The main character and the story so far seem quite interesting and I am intrigued about what will happen throughout the campaign, I also must say that the voice actor for the protagonist has done a really good job.

Overall, I'd highly recommend this game to anyone who has enjoyed any of the 90s FPS classics, although I'd probably tell you to wait until it gets fully released or you'll be thinking about the game every second of the day like I have, waiting for the next update to come out...

40543184.review:
Для меня, как и для многих, новость о выходе в ранний доступ этой игры стала неожиданностью. Я посмотрел скриншоты, посмотрел трейлер... увидел родной глазу движок Build и сразу понял, что надо брать. Затем я увидел постер и ещё больше проникся этой мыслью: ведь в постере прямая отсылка к Doom! Что это значит? Это значит, господа, что создатели оригинального Duke Nukem 3d уделили внимание и такой небольшой вещи, как постер. Обилие секретов и пасхалок всегда было одной из главных особенностей оригинального Дюка. Эта игра - настоящий наследник классики, это, можно сказать, второе пришествие старины Дюка, только в другом обличии.

Итак, превью кампания пройдена. Что мы имеем? Улучшенный движок Build - есть. Ламповая, олдскульная графика - есть. Харизматичный протагонист - есть. Классический экшен - есть. Секреты, пасхалки, чёрный юмор - есть. Да, здесь есть всё, что было в Duke Nukem 3d, а теперь даже лучше! Поддержка воркшопа в релизной версии тоже радует. Ещё и мультиплеер обещают, что тоже очень неплохо. Короче, хватит читать обзоры, олдфаги, эта игра обязана быть в вашей библиотеке!

A delicious and engaging throwback to everything we loved from the halcyon days of Build engine games. While there's still a little bit more that can be done for the humor, the action and visuals are spot-on from that time. If you have a hankering for a game that might as well have leaped out from 1995-97 then this is the one for you.

The preview campaign is short, and can be clocked in under or a little over an hour if you're not hunting for secrets, but even in a small package it shows promise. I'd still like an alt-fire mode, more weapons, but again it's basically the re-do of shareware episodes right now. I look forward to seeing the finished product!

This is a very well done Duke Nukem 3D spiritual sequel sharing not only the original engine, but also a lot of the original's look and feel. The preview offers a short campaign (about 4 levels, but one of them is the starting room and other is the boss fight) but it has good replay value with interesting maps, a ton of very well placed secrets, and a fun bombs-only mode.

As an early access title, the game misses some features (more weapons, more enemies, alt-firing mode, more interactivity with the scenery, sound variety, better balancing, and surprisingly needed optimizations) but it is already a polished, fun experience.

Gameplay is exactly  what you'd  expect it to be. Like Duke 3d,  Shadow Warrior Classic etc. Gunplay, level design, everything.

BUT...

There are some optimization issues.. I'm playing on an i7 4790k, gtx 970, 16 gb ram and there is some stuttering now and then, and this isn't just during the times when the game auto saves. I had to lock my framerate to 60 to have some consistency, but I could feel the jitter even when the fps was capped at 60. V sync was off, and I'm not talking about screen tearing when the game's locked at 60.

I have an Ultrawidescreen monitor, and 21:9 is pretty good, but I do see some inconsistencies on both sides of my screen now and then, like some clipping, when I get close to a wall, but it's not something that would bother you enough. But I hope the devs polish this out.

So taking  everything  into account, the game's good, only needs optimizing and polishing. And of course, the rest of the levels lol.

[h1]100% Genuine 90s FPS Greatness![/h1]

OK so I just finished my playthrough and I'm super happy with my purchase. It's every bit as good as the 90s build engine games we loved back in the day - if not better. 

Some people might think what I'm about to say is blasphemy but I personally like the new protagonist, Shelly “Bombshell” Harrison, better than Lo Wang and Duke! Not quite as charismatic as Caleb at this stage yet but who knows how the full version will develop her. I hope she has a lot more voice lines in future levels.

The weapons and maps expecially really shine. A small nit-pick but I wish the enemies had more satisfying death sounds (screams) maybe? Blood mastered this.

The secrets are master-crafted. Just excellent. Very original, never too easy, and so many of them, but always a great sense of accomplishment with every one. Lots of in-jokes and humour, too.

Surprisingly had some choppy framerate issues but after some tweaking was eventually able to sort that out and now running at 1000fps+!

Excellent game. Every bit as good as the amazing screenshots look. Actually, it's now my No. 1 game I'm looking forward to release right now. Instant classic.

40519487.review:
I've been expecting a return of Build-engine style games for a while now. After all, this style of FPS (sprite-based, pseudo-3d) has often been the key gaming experience for people of my generation (born in the late eighties), who are now old enough to make a mark on game development. And so we see a wave of retro shooters arriving that attempt to recreate the style of Duke Nukem 3d, Blood and Shadow Warrior. Ion Maiden is one of such games, developed using an updated version of the actual Build code, with improvements originating from the eDuke32 source port project. Does it succeed in its aims?

After playing through the currently available preview campaign I'm happy to report that it definitely is on the right track. The most important element of these games for me was the level design, and here the devs are showing considerable skill. The current stages are set in a metropolis struck with some apocalyptic calamity. We get to travel through an office building with some neighboring city streets and a metro station with adjacent underground tunnels. It's an obvious homage to Duke 3d but the style adds some good 'neon synthwave' elements (with a fitting tracker-style soundtrack). Importantly, the layouts and level of detail are amazing, especially in the first (above ground) section. The maps are sprawling and splendidly decorated with vintage sprites, filled with small interactive elements like light switches and destructible furniture. And there are secrets around every corner, many even requiring environmental interactions, like pushing objects. Completing the preview took me about an hour and a half and I had a great time. Finding all 32 hidden areas is surely a task for a few hours.

The combat is simple but quick and lethal, as expected in this style. You can make your way carefully and take cover around corners, but a more aggressive circle-strafing style is also completely viable. The enemy hordes of cyborgs don't exhibit any special intelligence and go down easily, but are satisfying to mow down. Arsenal consists of an electrified baton (which actually x-rays the enemies), a revolver, a shotgun and an Uzi-type submachine gun, which all feel reasonably powerful. A more original invention is the explosive munitions, called the 'Bowling bombs', which roll on the ground and home in on monsters. They are extremely powerful and can be used for some tricks, like rolling them under a partially open door. Overall the combat captures the essence of retro FPS and complements the exploration based gameplay. True to the style, we also get a talking protagonist with many sarcastic one-liners (even if I feel that the voice actress could use a more varied inflection).

So what I would like to see in the full campaign? More variety in enemy types and behavior - like flying ones. Original, signature guns, like old Caleb used to have. Stages that go beyond the urban/industrial setting. And some more technical polish, as the game tends to stutter in intense moments. I was also surprised to see common Half-Life-type mini loadzones. But overall I can almost guarantee that any fan of the classic 2.5D shooters will enjoy the current 2-level mini campaign. And I have very high expectations for the final full release.

*** I've only played through the pre-release campaign  (3 of 3 missions complete)*** 

It's been a great year thus far for 90's inspired First-Person Shooters (shout out to DUSK for kicking it off right!). Ion Maiden continues this trend with a build engine entry that feels like it would be right at home alongside other build engine classics of that era (Duke Nukem 3D, Redneck Rampage, Powerslave, Shadow Warrior, Blood, etc). However, you get the feeling from the first few minutes of playing that the developers clearly have taken the development wisdom, learned in the years since build was prominently used, to create a wonderfully refined FPS experience. The pixel art is gorgeous, the weapons are wacky and unique, and the great level design will be a treat for those that love exploring to find every last secret. I for one can't wait to play the final release.

Definitely recommend.

40513300.review:
A wonderful throwback to the 3D Realms games I grew up with as a kid. The maps are spacious, full of detailed objects and texture, great enemy placements where spawns don't feel cheap, and alternate routes to take! I'd say the maps are wonderfully and masterfully created. Some of the weapons just feel underpowered. The shotgun feels more like an SMG with burst fire, rather than a shotgun should feel. The spread isn't what I had imagined and it felt like a dissapointment. The revolver is kickass but I can't seem to fan the hammer! If that's a later mechanic added then I'm more than excited to see it. Bowling bombs are a hit and miss with me. Some times they'll lock on and other times, even when an enemy is in front of me, just decides to roll around him and target someone else. It's more like taking out one target rather than a larger group which is the purpose of a grenade.  A few notable problems I've noticed with the engine: 
[*] Framerate drops to 0 for a second or so which can really ruin the flow and intensity of the game. It'll throw your mouse around so you have to fix your aim and get readjusted to your surroundings. I normally clock in at around 1000 FPS LOL so that could be an underlying issue for me to fix.

[*] No quicksaving! Now that's more of a personal nitpick than anything, but I hate having to manually save before I move to a dangerous area and want to, again, keep the flow of the game going.

[*] Reloading in a Build engine game just seems.. unnecessary? Reloads take waaayyy too long and there really is no point in even having this mechanic. Like others have mentioned, if it's kept, at least change reloading speeds?

Other than those glaring issues I've come across, I'd like to say thanks to the team who has taken the time and dedication  to create an amazing throwback to their 90s hits with a modern twist. I can't wait for the full release in Q3 guys!

40509349.review: I blasted through the Preview Campaign, and it was solid. The weapons are fun to use, the maps are larger and more detailed than anything I've seen in a Build game, but still offer alternate routes and non-linear exploration. There are no procedurally generated levels or overly pixelated low-res graphics here. The difficulty could use some balancing, but the game is still in early access, so this will probably improve. Ion Maiden is an excellent showcase for new development in retro spaces. Besides the few quirks that come with the territory, this is a technical marvel that breathes new life into the gameplay styles of yesteryear. Anyone who still holds a candle for Duke or loved recent games like Shadow Warrior 2 should jump onto this Build Engine triumph. As for the future, here’s hoping that Ion Maiden‘s full release can give Shelly the game she deserves. We’ve hailed to the king since ’96, and every king needs his queen.

Want to know more? My full Early Access preview is now avialable on [url=https://techraptor.net/content/3d-realms-ion-maiden] TechRaptor [/url].

40508730.review:
Pros and Cons of this preview campaign:

Pros:
- Gameplay is excellent, a real throwback to the 3D realms' holy trinity of Duke Nukem 3D, Shadow Warrior and Blood.
- Level design is excellent.
- Secrets everywhere.
- Most of the weapons feel great to use, particularly the bowling bomb.
- interactivity is pretty good.
- Music is great.
-Spritework is awesome.
-It actually matters where you shoot enemies! With headshots dealing more damage, and shots to the body dealing less damage, unlike the other 3d reams games where it doesn't matter where you shoot them. I love this.

Cons:

- The reloading time for the SMG 9000 is way too long. It takes around three seconds or so to reload it, which massively kills the fast pace of the combat. The fact that you need to reload it so frequently doesn't help with this. Please increase the reload speed of it, or remove the reloading entirely.

- Please let us dual-wield the SMG-9000 in the full game. Please. For Lo Wang.

- A few of the one-liners are flat-out bad, in my opinion. "Cleanup on aisle 'your ass'"? Jesus christ... please remove this stinker in the real version.


Overall:

I tell you what though, you've got something really special going right here. I reckon this will be the Duke Nukem Forever we always wanted. I really like this preview campaign, and I'm hyped as hell to see the full game's release. For anyone looking to buy this, you might think the game is a little overpriced for just two levels, but you couldn't be any more wrong. Nearly everything about these two levels are so awesome that I find myself coming back and playing them again and again. For that reason, I think this game is certainly worth its asking price.

40502696.review:
Finally, 3D Realms proves it can return to fighting form post Duke Nukem Forever.

Ion Maiden is not a groundbreaking title. As you can clearly see, it's specifically going for the retro FPS market. And thank God, because it's probably one of the best FPS titles I've played in the last couple years, and that's just going off the early access episode. 

It' everything that that us first-generation fraggers want from a title: Great level design, the ability to skillfully mow down swarms of baddies, tons of secrets, and no BS handholding ie regenating health and quasi-lightgun duck and cover shootouts (although I admit I used the "IMGOD" cheat the first time for the boss encounter...it was kind of BS on hard mode). Think Shadow Warrior on steroids, as this game used the same core engine (Build), although a greatly enhanced and more stable version. 

Bombshell may have been a dud, but at least they show the character has promise. Hopefully the full title sticks to the formula that made this such a nostalgic and magical experience for me. Can't wait for the full game

PS Also runs like a dream under WINE on Linux Mint 18.1
EDIT: Just found that this game runs natively on linux as well. Runs even better that way.

40502603.review:
Played for only an hour so far, I know. But I've loved every second of it. Not saying this for any political purpose, but I thoroughly enjoy playing as a female protagonist in an oldschool-styled shooter like this. It feels just as badass as playing as Duke or Caleb.

If your reading this, developers, I have a few minor suggestions and issues. 

Some of the random voice lines pop up too frequently. It gets a little repetitive. I am assuming you will add more, however.

I had a few random spaz outs, where my crosshair flung to the ceiling, bear in mind I am using a PS4 controller.

On the topic of controllers. I totally get the genre and I know it flourishes on keyboard/mouse. Though I've recently been suffering a bit of RSI and I am no longer using a mouse. It would be great if this game had slightly improved controller support. Like, its not bad at all, but swapping weapons is a little annoying and aiming is a bit of a bitch (I am probably not used to the aiming is all). Maybe there is some way to imrove upon the weapon switching at the very least. Navigating the menu with a controller is also a tad irritating. 

Overall, I think this is the best game I've played all year, and I respect you (developers) so much for creating a banger for the fans of the genre and engine.

Cheers!

I can't tell - Is this made solely for those that remember the 90's classics made with the same engine or not? As someone that has played every Build title - this actually managed to feel fresh again! The enhancements made to the engine don't take away from the end product at all - they just make it better, if you can believe that. 

I stayed on this page for a while before actually adding it to my cart if I'm honest, but as it turns out I don't regret it!!! Why? Because this preview campaign (as they call it) was crafted with a particular attention to detail, and with a lot of love on top! If this preview was any indication then we're in for an awesome new game made with the Build engine in 2018! That ladies and gentlemen is an arrangement of words I never thought I'd write again, but I'm really happy I was able to. :) 

All fanboy stuff aside - This is starting to look like the best Build has provided in terms of quality and features since Shadow Warrior. It's really shaping up into something special, so I hope the full game is as good as what they gave us in the preview!! If I had anything to say it would be that I want to hear more from Shelly in terms of dialog. She speaks in the preview but for me in the full version I sure hope she speaks more. In my defense - I haven't found all the secrets and easter eggs in the preview so maybe I'm wrong here, but I don't think she speaks nearly as much as the others in the previous games. Make no mistake though, this was really fun, and I am looking forward to Q3 so I can play it all!  

To answer my initial question though.....

I feel that regardless if you're someone that has played the earlier titles or someone that hasn't - Both parties can appreciate the labor of love here, because its more than that!
